data.title: X-rays reveal half-billion-year-old insect ancestor
data.meta_description: The creature, the size of a poppy seed, dates back 520 million years and is almost perfectly preserved.
data.text:
The internal anatomy of a prehistoric creature the size of a poppy seed has been revealed in âastonishing detailâ.

Researchers used powerful X-rays to scan the 520-million-year-old fossil.

The results, published in the journal Nature, external, reveal its microscopic blood vessels and nervous system.

It is a peek inside the body of one of the earliest ancestors of modern insects, spiders and crabs.

Lead researcher Dr Martin Smith said this was a dream fossil, in part because it was preserved in its larval, or immature, stage - when its body was still developing.

âLooking at these early stages really is the key to understanding how those adult [body shapes] are formed - not just through evolution but through development.

âBut larvae are so tiny and fragile, the chances of finding one fossilised are practically zero â or so I thought.â

Dr Smithâs colleagues found the fossil in a pile of âprehistoric gritâ during a study of half-billion-year-old rock deposits in the north of China known to contain microscopic fossils.

âOur collaborators in China have large amounts of this stuff, which they dissolve it in acid and these little bits fall out,â Dr Smith said.

A team of technicians at Yunnan University spent years sifting through the material and picking fossils out of the dust.

After examining this particular specimen under the microscope during a trip to China, Dr Smith said, he had realised it was âsomething very specialâ and asked if he could bring it back to the UK to have a closer look.

The team mounted the fossil on the head of a pin in order to scan it with intense X-rays at Oxfordâs Diamond Light Source, external facility. That is where its internal secrets were revealed.

âWhen I saw the amazing structures preserved under its skin, my jaw just dropped,â Dr Smith said.

Researchers generated three-dimensional images of miniature brain regions, digestive glands, a primitive circulatory system and even traces of the nerves supplying the larvaâs simple legs and eyes.
